clusters.title: Two Australian men allegedly supplied guns to rebel group in Indonesia that kidnapped NZ pilot
clusters.neutral_headline: Australian Men Charged with Supplying Guns to Indonesian Group

items.title: Two Australian men allegedly supplied guns to rebel group in Indonesia that kidnapped NZ pilot
items.standfirst: Two Australian men have been charged with allegedly trafficking guns to a violent paramilitary group in Indonesia responsible for kidnapping a New Zealand pilot.
items.content: Two Australian men have been charged with allegedly trafficking guns to a violent paramilitary group in Indonesia responsible for kidnapping a New Zealand pilot.A joint taskforce — comprised of officers from the Australian Federal Police, ASIO, Queensland Police and New Zealand Police — was established after members of the National Liberation Army of West Papua kidnapped Phillip Mehrtens in the Indonesian province in February 2023.Mehrtens was taken after landing a small aircraft at a remote airstrip at Paro Airport and held for 592 days before being released in September 2024.READ MORE: Police separate two opposing groups of protesters in MelbourneThe two-year investigation has now led to the arrest of a 64-year-old man from NSW and a 44-year-old man from Queensland.Police allegedly found evidence linking the pair to the trafficking of guns from Australia to Indonesia. "The use of these deadly and illegal weapons can have far-reaching consequences if they reach the wrong hands," AFP Assistant Commissioner Stephen Nutt said. Police will allege the men tried to traffic guns and ammunition to the National Liberation Army of West Papua, and discussed sourcing Australian military guns for the group.The 64-year-old allegedly travelled to the province to meet with members of the group between March and April last year and allegedly took an optical rifle scope into Indonesia.Police searched their homes in November and allegedly found several items, including ammunition and 13.6kg of mercury metal.READ MORE: Timeline shows how Charlie Kirk's shooting and arrest of suspected gunman unfoldedThe 64-year-old was charged with exporting tier 2 goods, conspiracy to traffic prohibited firearms or firearm parts out of Australia, unlawful supply of weapons and possession of a controlled substance.He is facing up to 55 years' imprisonment.The 44-year-old was charged with exporting tier 2 goods and possessing explosives without authority, which could see him jailed for almost 11 years.The pair have appeared before court and have been granted bail to b oth face the Brisbane Magistrates Court on October 17."This was a complex investigation involving a number of jurisdictions and challenges, and our focus was always on the safe return of Philip Mehrtens," New Zealand Police Acting Deputy Commissioner Mike Pannett said.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: Two Australian men were charged with gun trafficking.
The men allegedly supplied guns to a violent paramilitary group.
The group is responsible for kidnapping a New Zealand pilot.
One man is from Queensland, the other from New South Wales.
The charges relate to alleged links to firearms trafficking.

items.title: Health ministers agree to new fertility sector accreditation regime – as it happened
items.standfirst: This blog is now closedAustralia’s biggest gas project greenlit to 2070 with ‘partial’ protection for Indigenous rock artGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastAustralians are dying from dementia more than any other disease, as advocates warn the number of people with the disease could exceed 1 million without government intervention, AAP reports.Dementia accounted for almost 17,400 deaths in 2023, equivalent to almost one in 10 of all deaths, according to the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare.This has been an entirely unedifying week for the Coalition. Not something that we want to repeat. Something we should learn from.I think there has been mishandling on all sides, but the good news is we have cauterised the wound. We are going to move on now and talk about what’s important to ordinary Australians. Continue reading...

Not something that we want to repeat. Something we should learn from.I think there has been mishandling on all sides, but the good news is we have cauterised the wound. ai_summary: Political leaders are making their own arrangements.
This is happening in the absence of United States leadership.
Putin's drone actions are a factor in the shift.
Netanyahu's strikes also contribute to the geopolitical shift.
The Middle East and Europe are experiencing changes.

clusters.title: Hidden risks of frequent flyer points and one traveller's $5,000 lesson
clusters.neutral_headline: Frequent Flyer Points Offer Poor Value, One Traveler Learns

items.title: Hidden risks of frequent flyer points and one traveller's $5,000 lesson
items.standfirst: Millions of Australians are signed up to airline loyalty schemes, but a new global ranking finds travellers are getting poorer value than from overseas carriers.
items.content: Millions of Australians are signed up to airline loyalty schemes, but a new global ranking finds travellers are getting poorer value than from overseas carriers.

ai_summary: Millions of Australians use airline loyalty schemes.
A new global ranking shows poor value for travelers.
One traveler learned a $5,000 lesson about the schemes.
Travelers are getting less value than from overseas carriers.
The schemes may not be as beneficial as they seem.

clusters.title: Armani's will surprises with instructions to sell brand or list on stock market
clusters.neutral_headline: Armani's Will Contains Unexpected Company Sale Instructions

items.title: Armani's will surprises with instructions to sell brand or list on stock market
items.standfirst: Giorgio Armani's will has surprised fashion watchers as it contains instructions to gradually sell off his company to a luxury brand or seek a listing on the stock market, in seeming contrast to his fiercely independent stance throughout his career.
items.content: Giorgio Armani's will has surprised fashion watchers as it contains instructions to gradually sell off his company to a luxury brand or seek a listing on the stock market, in seeming contrast to his fiercely independent stance throughout his career.

ai_summary: Giorgio Armani's will has surprised fashion industry observers.
The will instructs the gradual sale of his company.
The company may be sold to a luxury brand.
Alternatively, the company may seek a stock market listing.
This contrasts with Armani's independent stance.
